name: swash
content:
swash noun
(WATER)
Add to word list
Add to word list
[ C ] a narrow area of water in a sandbank or between the sandbank and the shore: The areas that would be affected the most would be low-lying places that are already prone to flooding now - such as some of the swashes at Garden City Beach.
[ U or S ] the movement of liquid, especially the water that moves up a beach as a wave comes in, or the sound that it makes: They studied the entire range of waves in shallow water from breakers to swash. When a wave breaks, water is washed up the beach and this is known as the swash. Compare
backwash
More examplesFewer examplesSeptember is the time when crowds disappear and the seabirds recolonize the swash. The white foamy swash of the water lapped gently on to the shore.I listened to the gentle swash of the water against the sides of the vessel.

swash noun
(IN WRITING/PRINTING)
[ C ]
  publishing
  specialized an extra line that is added to a letter or other symbol when it is written or printed, to make it look more impressive: Swashes were inspired by handwriting and were used as decorative elements. Swash characters are decorative letters that have an extended stroke, usually at their beginning or end.

swash noun
(BEHAVIOUR)
[ U ] informal humorous confident and brave behaviour, like that of a fighter in the past: You could not ask for a better actor to play Lancelot - he's full of swash and bold self-confidence. See also
swashbuckler

swash verb
(LIQUID)
[ I ] (of liquid, especially water flowing up or down a beach) to move: It was a sound rather like that of the sea swashing back over pebbles.
[ I or T ] to move like liquid, or to make something move like liquid: The passengers on the boat swashed from side to side. The candle fell to the floor, swashing hot wax over my dress.

swash verb
(HIT/FIGHT)
[ I ] to move your arm, or something that you are holding in your hand, in a powerful and uncontrolled way, in order to hit something: He swashed at the ball but missed.
[ I or T ] to fight with a sword in a confident way, like a fighter in the past: The actor Errol Flynn swashed on screen like no other of his time. On the Pirates of the Caribbean ride little boats glide around a series of caves where 100 animatronic figures swash and buckle their way through a piece of harmless fun. See also
swashbuckler
